I'm really torn... I love Mega Man.  It's my favorite series of all time!  I've played through the NES versions, the Genesis version, emulators on Windows, Android, PSP, and Dreamcast, the PlayStation Store releases of the Japanese PlayStation versions, the 3DS Virtual Console, the Wii Virtual Console, the Wii U Virtual Console, and the PS2 Anniversary Collection. I'm not exactly sorry I bought it... I do want to support Mega Man and show Capcom that the franchise deserves better.  But for serious play I'll probably go back to emulators.

reviewText:
Mega Man Legacy CollectionDeveloper: Capcom
Publisher: Capcom

Introduction
==========
The Blue Bomber has been around since 1987, and since then over 50 different titles bearing his name have been released. Selling over 30 million copies combined, Mega Man is often cited as one of the most renowned video game franchises of all time. However, Capcom has been neglecting him for the past several years, having cancelled the last few major Mega Man titles that were in developement (Mega Man Legends 3 being one of the biggest ones). It wasn't until Nintendo picked him up as a playable character for Super Smash Bros that we really started seeing more of him. That changes with the release of the Mega Man Legacy Collection, an updated re-release of Mega Man's first 6 iconic adventures from the NES glory days. While not as encompassing as the Mega Man Anniversary Collection that released in 2004, that included Mega Man 7 and 8 as well as 2 previously unlocalized Mega Man fighting games, it's still a great way to introduce new fans to the Blue Bomber's original adventures.

In addition to the six Mega Man games, Mega Man Legacy Collection features new ways to experience the classic games with the Museum Mode and new Challenge Mode. Challenge Mode remixes gameplay segments from all six games, with plenty of scaling difficulty objectives for experienced players to conquer yet serving as a good starting point for new players, too. Museum Mode contains a comprehensive collection of history, high-res art and original concept pieces – a treat for any fan of Mega Man and video game history.

Gameplay
==========
Featuring some of the most difficult 2D platforming, Mega Man plays out with the player controlling the Blue Bomber himself as he jumps and shoots his way through 6-8 stages, each with one of Dr. Wily's Robot Masters at the end. Defeating the Robot Master grants Mega Man a special interchangeable weapon for his Mega Buster, taken straight from the Robot Master he just defeated. Each stage has a certain theme, usually matched to the Robot Master. Players must be on top of their game to navigate each stage and defeat the Robot Masters, and ultimately Dr. Wily. Back in the day, game developers had to make their games incredibly difficult to extend the lengths of their games. Mega Man is one of the most difficult of the older game franchises, right up there with Castlevania and more.

Mega Man 1 is where it all began, featuring 6 stages with 6 Robot Masters. Each later title features 8 Robot Masters instead of 6. Mega Man 2 is probably one of the most memorable of the original 6 games, having one of the most overpowered weapons in the series: the Metal Blade. Mega Man 3 introduced sliding to the series, allowing Mega Man to traverse small spaces by sliding through them. Mega Man 4 introduced Charged Shots, where Mega Man charges his Mega Buster for a more powerful attack.

The most amazing feature this collection has is save states. If anyone has ever used an emulator, you'll be familar with what this means. Save states allow you to save anywhere in the game, at any moment, and then load those saves back up at anytime. Each title has 1 save state available to it, so make good use of them! I think they are best used as checkpoints during statges, or right before a boss so you can redo them over and over until you learn their attack patterns. This is probably considered cheating by some, but it's extremely useful.

Also available are a number of challenges, remixes to test your skills and abilities. Each one has a bronze, silver, and gold rating to aim for. Online leaderboards track the best players, and Replays allow you to watch them!

Graphics
==========
Mega Man is an 8-bit series, and this Legacy Collection does little to improve it. It does however add a few filters to give the nostalgic feel of playing on old televisions or PCs. The TV filter is probably the best one. Also available are widescreen and fullscreen options, as well as the original format.

As mentioned earlier, each title has an extensive collection of sketches and official art depicting characters and enemies from each game. These pieces of art are part of gaming history!

Sound and Music
==========
The Legacy Collection keeps the old 8-bit NES tunes and sounds of the series, and also offers a very nice music player for each of the 6 titles. Each title has around 20-25 tracks that can be played at anytime from the main menu. Boot up Dr. Wily Stage 1 from Mega Man 2 for a great example of the games' soundtracks!

Performance
==========
These games all run beautifully, and don't really take much at all. The game never crashed or had any issues. It runs at a steady framerate. If you want you are able to fully rebind any keys to your liking. Full controller support is also available, and is the recommended way to play. It's fully playable with a keyboard though.

Final Thoughts
==========
The Mega Man Lecgacy Collection is the perfect way to relive the glory days of Mega Man's 8-bit adventures, or introduce someone to the series. This collection is a must have for fans, and if enough people buy it we may see further Mega Man titles released on Steam. Capcom has neglected Mega Man for far too long, let's show them that he is still relevant and is still a beloved gaming icon!

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
A Must Play

reviewText:
Megaman returns in full blue-bomber glory! Though it could use a little more, it's an excellent collection that is totally worth your hard-earned cash to show Capcom that you care about this neglected series.

This collection only contains the first 6 NES Megaman games, which is probably my only complaint about the whole thing. I would have loved to see 7 through 10 here -- even just 9 and 10 since they fit the NES style. I, however, am a fan of even 7 and 8, and I firmly believe they deserve the same definitive collection treatment.

That aside, everything you could want is here. There's controller and keyboard support with full customization options.  You get screen scaling options that either maintain aspect ratio to a T for perfect pixels, stretch the screen only as far as it can go vertically, or completely fullscreen. If you're into CRT filters, they've got that too and they do a pretty good job. There's even an option for including a border around the game if you're using one of the non-fullscreen options. Quite honestly, I find it most comfortable to play with the proper aspect ratio. However, the game doesn't look or feel too bad in full screen.

The games all play just like I remember them in my brief experience going  back through. Included are also a music player which plays music from all 6 games, and there's a bunch of artwork and sketches to see and read about pertaining to the characters and enemies of each game. It's a nice little touch that shows extra effort. The challenges section is also a nice touch with some fun and addicting little speedrun challenges. Nothing revolutionary, they just run you through bosses and portions of stages. There's decent social integration with leaderboards and achievements and whatnot.

I've seen some people complain about the slowdown. Be assured that this is not due to actual framerate drops from poor optimization or something. These slowdowns are due to the fact that this collection is accurately emulated. This is the only collection of Megaman games released since the original NES version that perfectly emulates the NES hardware including all of the slowdowns. This is how Megaman played all those years ago, and the archiving of these games and all of their hardware flaws is good and necessary, in my opinion. I give Capcom a lot of credit for deciding to do this.

This is a good collection. If you like Megaman, buy this and show Capcom that you care. We all know how easy it is to emulate these games yourself, but there's no longer an excuse not to buy these games when such a great collection option exists at such a reasonable price.

reviewText:
Classic Showdown!
Megaman Legacy Collection brings the first 6 Megaman games to PC. But is this collection nothing more than just a bunch of emulated ROMs?

Well, that’s a very easy answer.

Pros:It’s Megaman!
I mean, seriously. It’s Megaman. The music, the colorful graphics, the presentation, it’s just very Megaman!
The Exclusive Challenges are surprisingly fresh, and gets really interesting when you warp from game to game in a single level.
Nitpicks:The “databases” and “artwork galleries” are nice additions but they just seem to be a excuse for additional content.
Cons:They’re all emulated, barely modified ROMs. It’s basically just a well-presented NES emulator that plays Megaman.
The Review
I’ll admit, I haven’t really grown up with the Megaman games. Prior to playing the collection, I played a brief session of Megaman 1, and I’ve later played the remake for it as well. But it’s so easy to see why Megaman is such a classic icon when it comes to video games. There was an element of strategy and challenge to defeating the bosses, and it makes a very elegant design. Once Megaman 2 cleared up most of the issues the original had, what did they do with this well-designed formula?

They copied it about 4 more times.

That’s not to say that the sequels didn’t have new mechanics/abilities, but playing through all of these games at once shows that each new game only added a small, marginal improvement. Which is perfectly fine, because if it ain’t broke (or stale), don’t fix it. Packing the first 6 games together makes them feel more coherent and similar (As if it was one large game), and that really makes exploring the history of such a legacy really great. And why would you change the stellar music, rock-paper-scissors mechanics, and challenging difficulty anyway? All they needed was a bit of spice each iteration to make it special.

But we’re here to talk about this re-release for the first 6 Megaman games, right? I wish I could go in-depth about how the re-release turned out but that would be completely boring. And this is because Megaman Legacy Collection is almost nothing more than a bunch of emulated ROMs placed into a emulator, with the emulated slowdown and everything. There’s virtually nothing different from the original NES releases, which is fine, but those expecting more will be severely disappointed. If there was one thing I wish they just changed for these releases, it would be the removal of the emulated slowdown. It makes the game seem slower than it actually is at times and it makes precise movement difficult. Most computers are already more capable of handling all of these sprites at once, why do we need to experience the same technical limits that occurred on the original release?

Note that I said “almost”. That’s because the game’s new form of content comes in the Challenges, which add a time trial element to the games. These mainly consist of both boss rushes and unique stages that take parts from different games and put them together in one level (Which is probably the coolest part of Legacy Collection). They’re nice additions that probably won’t attract the majority of the people that play the game. The other bonuses include art galleries, a playable music player for the game’s soundtrack, and info databases on all of the characters/enemies in each game. These are also neat additions, if a bit standard for some of these re-releases in general.

For the most part, that’s about mostly the entire game covered. There isn’t that much you need to know, other than that if you wish to play some Megaman, this is definitely worth picking up. If you want something more out of this collection (like more unique bonuses), then you’ll probably be out of luck.

TL;DR - [A simplistic, if somewhat underwhelming re-release that’s still very worth it for those wanting some Megaman action on PC.]

I'll get the one nitpick out of the way first:  There seems to be a very bad crashing problem when viewing the Leaderboards after accessing them straight away from completing a challenge.  Encountered a crashing problem while starting up the game, but was remedied by restarting Steam.

Onto the actual gameplay:  As far as I can tell, the controls are the exact same and behave the same as the cartridges I have sitting here right next to me.  Most of the input lag that people are experiencing may be first-timers or people who have seemed to forget that there are little silly control mechanics embedded in these games.  Like in Megaman 4, while in water you cannot jump out of a slide.  In Megaman 6, you cannot jump out of a slide at all.  Megaman 3 has awful lag issues, but it's always had that,  It can also eat you jump/megabuster if you press the button slightly before picking up a weapon energy or life capsule.   Say in Shadowman's stage, when you have to cross the ravine with the parachute bots coming from above, if you jump at the same time you kill them (say with Magnet Missle) and they drop a weapon energy that you then run into, it will eat your jump input and you will fall into the death pit.

It's just small things that some of us tend to forget after 20+ years of not playing these games.

I have played around with challenge modes for a few hours, and they're an enjoyable little addition.  Great to hone in on your platforming skills.  I have also completed all 6 games start to finish and I cannot distinguish any greatly disparaging differences from the original titles.  They play 99% the same.

I do not think the $15 price point is steep at all, considering the original games can cost you anywhere from the $15 itself, to upwards of $60 depending on where you look.

reviewText:
While the Mega Man Legacy Collection is geared more toward new players than longtime fans, the amount of content you get is easily worth the price of admission.

First off, you get six of the most celebrated games in the series. Everyone has their favorites, but you'd be hard-pressed to find a true fan who won't at least tolerate all the NES games, let alone absolutely love them. The games look, sound, and feel exactly as they do on the original hardware, with the added bonus of being able to save your game at any time (rather than writing down the password at the end of each stage). I've heard a few complaints about slowdown and controller lag, but after several hours of game time, I haven't experienced anything out of the ordinary.

Second, there is a database for each game that contains informative and amusing tidbits about the characters and enemies, along the lines of what you'll find in the Robot Master Field Guide or the CD database in Mega Man & Bass. Futhermore, each game has its own art gallery full of concept sketches and official illustrations, like a condensed version of the Mega Man: Official Complete Works book.

Third, there is a music player that allows you to listen to any of the tunes from any of the games at any time. It would've been a nice touch to keep the selected music playing in the gallery and database modes, so that you're not forced to listen to a cover of Mega Man 3's good but incredibly short password music on infinite loop, but unfortunately this feature is really just a glorified sound test. Still, it's a welcome inclusion.

Fourth, the game offers more than 50 time-driven challenges that mash up various parts of the six games in the collection. This is the one area where the collection falls short, however. A few sections (for example, the moving platforms in the beginning of Guts Man's stage) are used over and over, while entire stages (most notably the various fortress stages) are almost completely absent. For as much replay value as the challenges offer, too much of it is tedious and redundant. Some of the challenges are well constructed, though; themed challenges such as the boss rushes and All Appearing Blocks" are good fun

This collection provides you with everything it advertises: all 6 NES Mega Man games in one collection.

I hooked up my Xbox One controller and immediately dived into Mega Man 2. This collection doesn't just offer the games but also official artwork and the soundtracks to the games. Some may complain about the lag that occurs when multiple enemies appear on the screen, but that was a limitation of the original NES. The producers decided to keep the games as faithful to the originals, which was a good decision in my part. All the original glitches and bugs are also still included, which just add charm to these classic games

These games are far from impossible, but they definitely require some precision platforming and technique. Each boss can be defeated easily if you use his weakness against him, resulting in most of the difficulty coming from the platforming segments of each level. The games are fair and offer a simple, yet fun experience that anyone who doesn't suck can enjoy.

reviewText:
Before I start, I'll just say now that I'm going to be looking at this game from an objective standpoint and not comparing it to Anniversary Collection. While it would be easy to say that Anniversary Collection is the better purchase because it has more games, gives you more options like fast weapon switch, and all that good stuff, it is also a game that’s not on Steam, Xbox One, PlayStation 4, nor the Nintendo 3DS. The game also has its own fair share of problems, such as the god-awful sound quality for example, so it’s not like either game is free of problems and why I’ll only exclusively look at Legacy Collection by itself.


Mega Man Legacy Collection is a game that’s torn me both ways on really liking certain things about it and hating others, as well as unfortunately being indifferent to most of it. The goal of Legacy Collection is to try and be as accurate to the original NES titles as possible, so it does not make the games lagless nor does it fix any graphical issues or glitches found in the original games like zipping. The game also includes extra content such as a museum of high resolution official and concept art for all six games and a challenge mode with leaderboards. The challenge mode consists of timed objectives to do that range from defeating Yellow Devil in Mega Man 1 to completing an assortment of sections from stages from each game in the Megamix challenges. The game doesn’t do much else aside from these kinds of extras and then just the games themselves, so let’s look at the good and bad things about Legacy Collection.

THE GOOD:
+Colors are bright and vibrant
+Sound is really good, very crisp and clear (I swear there’s some instrumentation I hadn’t had heard before in some tracks)
+Some of the Megamix challenges are actually pretty fun
+Most of the border art looks fine
+Concept art in museum is incredibly detailed and is interesting to look through
+Database provides descriptions and weaknesses for enemies and bosses for all six games

THE BAD:
-Only has native controller support for Xbox 360 pads (you would need to use something like JoyToKey if you want to use an NES controller through an adapter like I do)
-No scans of each game’s manual in the museum
-Noticeable input delay if you’ve played these games before (I’d guess around 1 to 3 frames)
-Certain rooms are reused A LOT in challenge mode (Guts Man room 1 and Quick Man beam section is ridiculously overused in the MM1 and MM2 challenges) and some that are used don’t have anything going on besides just walking forward or climbing a ladder (one room used is near the end of Bomb Man’s level that only involves walking forward under two Flying Shell’s and then climbing a ladder)
-Autofire is not authentic to the original games and makes challenges like Yellow Devil MK-II and Mecha Dragon way too easy
-Main menu is very bugged and can improperly display everything to be white squares or can just randomly crash on startup if options were changed (this can be fixed by deleteing Options.sav under \AppData\Roaming\MegaMan\011000010009159F\)
-Severe lack of basic options (only controller mapping for keyboard, no sound options or anything)

As a whole I can only give this game a recommendation if you’re someone who hasn’t played Mega Man and wants to do so on an officially released title. The input lag likely won’t be noticeable enough for it to ruin the experience and the games themselves are preserved well enough that you’d get an experience close to the original NES. For someone who has played these games countless times and wants something more, I can’t really recommend buying this game. Obviously the six games aren’t what you’d be looking for if you’ve played them again and with the added input delay you’re not going to get much out of playing them again on this. The challenge mode does provide some fun stuff to play through, but with the amount of them that are either boring or flat out not fun to play through I can only really recommend this game on a sale. The best implemented features in this game are the museum and the soundtracks for each game, but even at that $14.99 is too steep of a price to pay for this rahter lacking title. Hopefully with the release and sales of this game, Capcom can develop an original Mega Man title, but at this point I’m not really expecting anything. So as far as new Mega Man content goes, the challenge mode in this is likely as close as we’ll get for a while.

I am sad to do this since I am fan of the Mega Man franchise since its first release on the NES, but I will have to give this Mega Man compilation a negative review due to the critical issues that surrounds the release build without a day 1 patch to address those issues.

I am not basing my review on the legacy issues that surrounds the original 6 games. Input lags, frame rate drops, sprites flickering, game exploits; all those were part of the original game and from the look of this, this game seems to be some short of emulator that runs the original games ROMS, making those issues legacy issues. I was expecting to encounter those legacy issues by purchasing this game. My primary intention of purchasing this game compilation was to be able to play the original 6 Mega Man games through legit means, but to also have access to its extra content and the Challenge Mode.

The critical issues that disappoint me are the ones from the compilation software itself, like the graphical issue that causes the game to show corrupted UI elements or even a blank screen, forcing the user to reboot their game’s application.

The game can even encounter stability issues with the game’s application causing it to crash by performing certain actions within the Leaderboard of the Challenge Mode.

But the issue that angers me the most is after completing all 6 Mega Man games the compilation offers, the user is unable to boot the game’s application anymore because the save file becomes corrupted, as if something was intended to be unlocked upon completing all the games but it is missing in the code and while the game attempts to boot, it crash due to the missing content. Though the cause of the crash is just an assumption and not the reason for the application to crash, but in the end the game’s application should crash and require the user to delete their save file to be able to play the game again.

The game also contain a few issues there and there with its new content like the Challenge Mode, like being able to be immortal by being not able to die due to damage inflected by enemies (though still being vulnerable to pitfalls and spikes). Though those issues are minor compared to the graphic issue and crashes.

Some of those issues are obvious issues and none seems to be low occurrences, so most likely the Q.A. team that was assigned to test the Steam version of the game was aware about those issues and so was the development team. So even though those issues were most likely known, Capcom decided as the publisher to push this build to the general public, allowing the public to pay for something that was not deem ready for the market, to which it disappoint me a lot.

If you don’t mind the legacy issues from the original games, I highly suggest you to wait for the critical issues that are related to the game software and not to the core of the original 6 games are fixed. Otherwise you will be annoyed by having to handle those issues.

reviewText:
Chances are you already own these games in some form, be it the NES versions or one of the many physical and digital ports. So why would you want to buy them all over again?

A good question. If you're not from Europe like I am, chances are you've played the Mega Man Anniversary Collection on PS2 or GameCube. That was a robust collection of all eight then-released Mega Man games plus two unlockable spin-off games. By comparison, Legacy Collection feels a little dissapointing when it comes to the number of games. This edition includes only the first six games in the classic Mega Man series, being the ones that were made for the NES console. The four sequels released on other systems, the most recent being 2010's Mega Man 10, are not included in this compilation. Anniversary Collection at least had 7 and 8.

One might argue that this re-release is a little cheap. With the split between Capcom and series creator Keiji Inafune, the Blue Bomber has been relegated to the side after being so wonderfully brought back to his roots just a couple of years ago. It's easy to see this compilation as a cheap way to keep fans happy. Making fans re-buy them will only happen you add something to the existing games.

Thankfully, it's not as bare-bones as just six games slapped together. This package has concept art, official artwork, playable soundtracks, and detailed descriptions for every enemy and character you encounter in each of the six games, which is sure to please long-time fans. Besides that, the main new attraction is a challenge mode that allows you to try and beat short sections of the games as quickly as possible in a Wario Ware or NES Remix-like fashion. It's a great way to add a modern spin on the familiar and it supports online leaderboards so even the most veteran Mega Man fans can see how good they really are in the grand scheme of it all.

Other than that, you still have six games just brimming with 8-bit goodness. The classic NES graphics don't just hold up well on their own, but also look nice and crisp in HD. If you prefer a more nostalgic look, you can even turn on a filter that makes it look like you're playing on an old CRT TV. The game can be played with black or illustrated borders or you can go for the stretched-to-full look of old. It's all up to you.

Gameplay-wise, these old games hold up remarkably well. Controls are responsive and the games are faithfully ported to the PC. Even the glitch that allows you to cheat against Mega Man 1's Yellow Devil boss is present for old time's sake. Wether you are familiar with these games or not, you will have a blast as long as old-skool difficulties do not turn you off. The games are still as fun as ever and have just about enough diversity and depth to make you want to keep trying despite the serious challenge. Each boss is weak to another one's weapon. Finding out the correct order in which to beat them is a great mix of logic and trial-and-error. It's as good as it was over twenty years ago and as faithful of an experience, compared to the NES, as you will ever have.

Sometimes it's even a little too faithful, though. You still experience things like slowdown and sprite flickering if there's a lot of stuff on screen. While this may add to the authenticity of the games, I just can't understand why there's no option to at least turn it off. New players might be put off by this, which is sad as these games are otherwise not dated at all and still some of the deepest, most satisfying platform experiences out there.

Overall though, it's still very easy to recommend this collection to anyone not familiar with Mega Man. Veterans really need to think about wether they feel the challengde mode and music/artwork extras are enough to keep them interested in games they have played to death. For those who may not have their old copies any longer, this is a fantastically affordable way to get them again. It's important to note that you can now save anywhere you want if you so desire, making the challenge a lot less meaty for those new players daunted by the difficulty of 80s and 90s gaming. If you're interested in getting into Mega Man for the first time, there is no better way to do so than by buying this for just fifteen bucks.

The biggest flaw is ultimately that the last four games aren't included in this package. I would very much appreciate if Capcom released these as well, either as DLC for this title or as a separate Legacy Collection Vol.2". On its own

The release of Mega Man Legacy Collection has been rather controversial with fans. Here are a few facts everyone should know:

-The NES cartridges have suffered remarkably from inflation, and aren't equipped with frustration pain killers (quick save features). Buy them if you want them. The controller is certainly more suitable.

-Mega Man Legacy Collection doesn't include 9&10. It would have been better if it did, just like if it had also included 7,8, Mega Man & Bass, and the entire X and Zero collections.

-Fifteen dollars is really not a lot of money, ya know? I've spent more for broken Early Access games. These are six of our favorite games of all time, with trophies, art, music, and challenges.

-You may think Capcom sucks because of their recent business methods, or for their treatment of the Mega Man producer and product in the past. That doesn't mean this package sucks.

reviewText:
I did a long form video review on my YouTube channel as well: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NlRWAZ8E6Mw

This is a package made by Mega Man fans, for Mega Man fans. It contains all 6 of the NES games in a very nice wrapper with meticulous emulation. This collection was developed by the newly revived Digital Eclipse, who have a stated focus of re-releasing older titles with a focus on accuracy and preservation. As their first effort, they did a bang up job here.

The emulation of the games is pixel perfect, including all the warts many NES games were famous for like lag and sprite flicker. The games run exactly as they did on the NES, for better and for worse. A variety of options are included to play them in different screen sizes (original, partially stretched and full widescreen stretched) and you can also add scanline filters and even a wavy RF modulator like filter if you're really nostalgic. Full keyboard and controller support are available and both work great and allow full button rebinding. There is game art to fill in the black bars if you aren't played in stretched mode but it isn't especially great and some of them are just creepy looking. Save states are also available but only one slot for each game which is weird. Multiple slots would be better.

The real value addition to this collection is the Challenge mode. A whopping 50 challenges are included, which are custom designed time attack gauntlets that will take you through a variety of small sections from all the different games. You are graded based on your completion time and full online leaderboards are available. Best of all, you can watch replays of any submitted leaderboard time, so you can watch some of the crazy speedruns that people have already done. Unfortunately, many of the challenges require that you complete previous ones not only to run them but even to see the leaderboards, which is a real bummer. I hope the ability to see leaderboards on all challenges gets patched in. These are great fun and made the somewhat hefty asking price of this collection much more worthwhile.

Ultimately, this is a fantastic and clearly lovingly crafted collection for Mega Man fans. However, if you weren't already a fan of the series or don't have an interest in retro games, this won't convert you. If you are one, the other or both though, this is a no brainer. The collection will also run on just about anything so if you want a great laptop game, you've found it here. Like Mega Man? Get this now!

reviewText:
It has the three essential games (1,2,3) and a couple of filler games. Presentation is fantastic, with a lovely aspect-corrected nearest neighbour mode; an even lovelier TV mode with a light dot crawl effect, scanlines, and a bit of motion blur; and just a regular scanline mode that basically looks like an RGB-modded NES running through an XRGB.

From everything I read, it sounds like they put a lot of effort into getting it to be as accurate to the games running on an original NES as possible. To that effect, there's no emulator weirdness, you get all the flicker and slowdown you'd expect, the palette is completely accurate, and it sounds fantastic.

Not much to say about the games themselves, because they're classics of the medium and among the best games ever made - at least the first three - and everyone who likes action games should play them. The latter three are technical showpieces that demonstrate the NES running at its absolute maximum capacity, but feel like they're starting to run out of steam.

The fact that this collection is only these games is fine, because these games ARE Megaman. The awkward late SNES/PSX years weren't kind on the little blue boy, so we're best left forgetting them. The only game I really wish was there was the triumphant return of classic Megaman, Megaman 9, but that does kind of exceed the scope of this collection. Wish there was a way to play Megaman 9 on the PC that doesn't involve ugly emulation through a Wii emulator, though...

Support classic rereleases that actually put effort into the presentation and accuracy of the games - buy this.

reviewText:
*pushes away all the bad reviews of this game*

Now that's out of the way, let me tell you, as a HUGE Megaman fan for years now, this collection is a great one. Other reviews are claiming it's a cash grab, or that it's a cheap version of the Anniversary Collection back over a decade ago, I want to elaborate that this game is Megaman 1-6 on a DIFFERENT ENGINE. Capcom designed an entire new engine and decided to port over Megaman 1-6, this means that's the reason why they didn't include Megaman 7, 8 or etc. Is this bad? Not at all.

This collection is an excellent collection of the classic 8-bit games that were on the NES. These are *NOT* emulated ports, these are the original games recreated on the NEW engine. This could mean Capcom is planning a Megaman revival soon, who knows. But I digress, this doesn't mean the game is bad. While yes, it may suffer from some input lag, it's nothing to fuss over. This game is an excellent addition to anyone who enjoyed the Megaman games from their childhood or anyone who's an entry level into the megaman series. The fact they included a remix mode and an online leaderboard really drives home for veterans of the series who are looking for a further challenge. In addition, the artwork and early sketches are a nice treat as well. There's not much I can say, other than the megaman games are hard, twitchy, side scrollingly fun!

So instead of looking at those bad reviews on people claiming how cheap or bad it is, consider it from a different perspective. You really can't go wrong with a $15 collection (About $2.50 per game) that's excellently ported over to a brand new engine that still feels like you're playing on an NES, and that's saying a lot since they totally could have just straight up emulated the games.

reviewText:
Didn't expect NES games to arrive on Steam, but here we are! This collection has the first six Mega Man games, and some fun extras on the side. A must for fans of classic Mega Man, but also good for people who like classic style hardcore games. If you thought Shovel Knight was fun and want more, welcome aboard.

Pros:
-On top of the expected six games, there's an in-depth glossary of every enemy and boss from every game, including what weapons work best against them. There was some info even I didn't know about, and I've been playing these games for years!

-Challenge mode is an interesting twist for Mega Man masters that want something new. Health and ammo carry over between different parts of a given challenge, even though they're from a variety of games. Ranging from a multi-level gauntlet from a variety of Mega Man games, or a boss rush of every Robot Master in the six games, there's plenty for hardcore fans to test their mettle against.

-Soundtrack mode. Does what it says on the tin, but appreciated all the same.

-Save States, allowing you to save and load anytime without relying on passwords. No shame in using them, they're there for a reason.

-The six Mega Man games are still as solid as ever. With good level design and tight controls (Mega Man 1 nonwithstanding), it's sure to be a good time for platforming fans.

Cons:

-Lack of options. You cannot change your screen resolution at all, there's no sprite smoothing option, there's Windowed or fullscreen, and a handful of cosmetic options. Having a screen filter that emulates old TV's and a arcade-style border to fill the black space is an ok tradeoff, but I'd rather have true fullscreen that doesn't stretch the game in odd ways.

-Sprite Flickering you cannot turn off. This was all but necessary in the NES era, so that there's enough memory to render a lot of sprites at once. Some people like this because of nostalgia, but it does make some moments nearly impossible (See: Mega Dragon in MM2). Many emulators are capable of removing sprite flickering, the fact Capcom didn't is a bit lazy.

-There are some truly unfair traps, especially in the endgame Wily Castle sections. Even vigilant save state usage can back you into a corner, forcing a reset. For the most part the games are a good time, but there are some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t challenges if you want to beat the games.

-While Challenge Mode is a good feature, it's tailored almost exclusively to people who have memorized the first six Mega Man games. There's little to no description on what the goal of each challenge is, and no suggestions on how to beat them. On top of that, each challenge drops the player into different parts of each game, some of which having different gameplay (for instance, no sliding or charge shot in MM1+2, slightly different physics in MM1, different weapons in each game). Unless you already know every game front to back, you're gonna have a rough time in Challenge Mode.

reviewText:
Ah, Mega Man. Classic Mega Man to be exact, my favorite portion of my favorite game franchise... or at least half of it. Yeah, this collection obviously contains only the first six (and the most iconic) Classic series games, so no 7-10 or &Bass here. Disappointing, maybe, but for fifteen bucks for these titles and a challenge mode, I'd say it's worth that price, especially if you're new to the Blue Bomber. Besides, these are the games most people hold so highly anyway, considering I generally hear 7, 8 and &Bass are looked down upon (I disagree with 7 and &Bass, but 8 can die). I'll cut the rambling now and go on to the Pros and Cons of this collection.

Pros:

The six NES Mega Man originals, preserved and in much higher quality and resolution compared to emulators or the NES for that matter.

Switching between games on the fly is a good feature, so props for the no-hassle menus.

Boss practicing via Database.

Challenge mode with leaderboards, prompting competition and replayability.

Filters replicating an old '80s TV or a monitor.

No input lag unlike the Anniversary Collection! Quality > quantity.

Retains the original funny misspellings like 'Wiley' and 'My scheme for world domination has faild!'

Fair price for all mentioned above plus the Museum and music player.

----------------------------------

Cons:

Monitor filter has a habit of causing all sprites to literally disappear in sections of Mega Man 1 and 2 with sprite flickering (namely, the Boobeam Trap).

Games feel a little less responsive than they should be. A lot of times I find myself unable to jump over a wall while running into one. I could do so just fine when I played these games elsewhere.

No options to turn off sprite flickering and lag. I know these ports are supposed to be accurate to the original NES carts, but at the very least give people the option (I don't mind so much because purist).

Challenge mode is, while a nice idea on paper, gets way too repetitive if challenges are played alongside one another in one single sitting. They tend to reuse a lot of sections like Air Man's annoying fan enemies with the birds or Guts Man's platform section.

---------------------------------------------------

That said, this collection is definitive for newcomers interested in seeing what our robotic hero has to offer in what was his glory days. However, for a series vet like me, you're generally one of two things: 1. someone who already owns these games in another format and doesn't see a reason to buy this collection, or 2. someone who buys this because it's Mega Man and you love him that much (and I'm guilty of that. I bought the 3DS Collector's Edition version of this collection as well). In terms of the games themselves which is the main reason you probably even care about this, I'd give it a 9/10. Accurate to the originals in almost every aspect, and if you're not obsessed like I am you probably won't even notice those tiny things. It's worth picking up at some point, if not only for the novelty of these classics.

reviewText:
I grew up playing Mega Man on the NES and I resisted purchasing this for about 3 days. I want to show support and interest for the series, though, and enough reviews convinced me to buy it. I'm glad I did.

So, technical stuff:
As others have noted, these games are recreated identically to their NES origins, warts and all. Honestly, Mega Man 1 is fun until Wily's castle, after which the amount of slowdown plagueing boss fights makes the save states almost a necessity. The same is true for MM2 in one fight, and the early games suffer from poor game design (weapon energy doesn't recharge between Wily stages, for example). Save states make up for this, but players who are unaware of these odd problems in the first two games may find them especially frustrating. I'm wondering if people have mistaken the slowdown for poor performance or software bugs. Given how rough it is in MM1, it's a questionable decision not to fix some of it.

That said - I experience no performance issues on my fairly low-end machine, and zero input lag. These games look and feel exactly as they did when I was 8 years old, which is great for me but may frustrate new players.

The monitor filter is great. Initially I didn't care for it, but once I got used to it, it looks exactly like my old tube TV did on NES games. I've hated these filters on emulators before but this one feels perfect.

Given there are a multitude of ways to purchase and play these games legitimately, this is certainly the best way to do so. At $5 a game on Virtual Console services, getting this package for essentially $2.50 per game on top of all the challenges is a great deal. Truly wish they included MM9-10 though, since they were done just like NES games.

reviewText:
It should go without saying that Mega Man is one of those games that defined the action platformer genre back in the late 80's and early 90's. Though it doesn't seem like I've put many hours into this game here, trust me when I say that I've played and finished every game included in this set (1-6), 7, 9 and 10 (I never got the chance to play 8 unfortunately), and that these games are worth the current price of 15€.

There are extras included in this set, such as art, music and gameplay challenges. And while it does seem all well and good, it does feel like it was rushed a bit. The art isn't really categorized by any other way except which game it belongs to, a lot of the challenges are just small parts of the games put into a section that you have to clear, little things like these. They don't really take away from the experience, but they sort of make it seem like everything was rushed.

There are also some decisions made that I don't really agree with, such as autofire and having the ability to save your game at any point in the game and then being able to load it up pretty much any time you want. First of all, autofire is for wimps! Am I right? ... No? ... Ok, sorry. Second, I'm not entirely comfortable with being able to save and load at will, because you can just come up to a hard part, save, die and then load your game again like nothing happened. It sort of negates the reason why the Mega Man games had lives to begin with. Maybe if you used the saving system after every boss instead of the password system from 2-6, I'd be happy with it. But overall, I can't say that they're bad things to have. If anything, it will probably make more people enjoy the Mega Man series. Besides, they're entirely optional. If you want to play the games without saving or using autofire, you can choose to do so by not even acknowledging that they exist.

In conclusion, it's classic Mega Man with a built in autofire and the option to save and load your game at will, along with gameplay challenges, soundtrack and art. What's not to love?

reviewText:
Shortly put, the Jump button in this game is adhorrently unresponsive, which alone says it all. Jumping is as important in Mega Man as stealth in Metal Gear or flying in Flight Simulator. And if such core mechanics won't work, you just can't shrug that off. It fundamentally breaks the game. Just imagine if you suddenly were unable to pick up blocks in Minecraft (in survival or creative mode, that is).

Far too often, jumping doesn't even register. And the times it does, there's commonly a delay from when you press the button till you actually jump. These things make pixel-perfect edge jumping and similar almost impossible, and there's a plethora of situations in this game where jumping multiple times in a row and timing it correctly is key. And you can forget about speed running these games, as it stands now.

My Background:

I've played these games on both the NES and through emulators, so this isn't about the games being too hard for me. Mega Man 2 is my most played-through game of all time - easily 200+ playthroughs, culminating in a 27-minute speed run. For the Mega Man Legacy Collection, I also happened to have a new keyboard (that works perfectly with every other game I have, old as well as new ones).

In MMLC's defense, I have NOT tested the game on a controller.

In Conclusion:

If Capcom fixes the shoddy controls and makes the games feel properly responsive, you are in for an amazing game experience. The Mega Man series has some of the best NES games ever, and Mega Man 2 is, imo, the greatest NES game ever designed (from a level design perspective).

The fact that 7, 8 and 9 aren't included in this collection, is incidental IMO. Those games are barely worth playing - it's always been Mega Man 1 thru 5 that have been acclaimed as pinnacle titles, and I guess Mega Man 6 too. I can understand how the bigger fans would like 7, 8, 9 though - it makes the collection feel incomplete.

In either case, for my own sake, I just have to go with what I'm experiencing right now. And right now, I have very little good to say about the experience.

Booh, CAPCOM. Please fix this!

reviewText:
Let's face it- blowing up robots is awesome. Blowing them up and taking their special powers for personal use? Even better. Such is the premise of the Megaman series- a system that has influenced game design since its launch in 1987 (and which I remember playing on a console a year later, when I was six. I feel rather old at that realization).

The premise is rather simple- take the first bunch of stages in any order, amassing a pile of special weapons to take down the evil Dr. Wily and save the world from his latest evil scheme (yeah, it's safe to assume he doesn't really have a hobby) by blasting through Skull Castle . While the full Megaman series consists of several different games spread over how many consoles and time periods, this collection contains only a small slice of all that- for fifteen bucks retail, you get a pretty decent selection: the first six games of the main Megaman series, which were all released on the eight-bit Nintendo Entertainment System over a period of time from 1987 to 1994. You also get some behind-the-scenes stuff, like enemy backgrounds art assets and sketches, as well as the soundtracks to the six games (trust me, you'll run into plenty of earworm-type songs in these games) but I honestly don't understand why you'd include a music player when you could just fire up YouTube and listen to them there without having to go and boot Steam.

You also get a challenge mode- which shows lots of influence from a series of fangames that just throw you into sections from random levels and see how far you can get. This is actually rather fun- your powers are determined by which game you land in, and you get four E-Tanks to sustain you through the sequence, and you're scored on time taken. This forces you to think on your toes and use your memory to try and think of all your options at the current time.

There's a save system- you get one save point for each game that you can use to save at any point- just go into the menu, save, and it will allow you to load the game and pick up at that exact point. It's useful for when you're at the end of a level on your last life, and don't desire to play the level again.

This is also one of the only legitimate ways to get copies of these games outside of A) owning the original cartridges, B) buying the Megaman Anniversary Collection, or C) buying them off of Nintendo's Shop Channels (1 to 5 are on the Wii Shop channel, 6 is on the Wii U and 3DS shop channel). But that, well... leads into a bit of the downside to this collection.

Why is this only the first six games? There are ten in the main series alone, and you've got the main series, the X series, the Legends series... why not just tweak the Anniversary Collection and release that and ask twenty or twenty-five for it? Follow it up with the X Collection and the Legends games and you have a great way to reach another generation of gamers through Steam. Also, why no Wily Wars?

All of the games enclosed within are faithfully emulated, down to the screen flicker and original bugs and easter eggs (the Elec Beam/pause trick still works in the first game, and you can still get the Rush Jet in 3 without having to earn it if you know the trick). However, that means the sprite flicker and slowdown is in there, too.

The early games- especially the first game- are genuine Nintendo hard. The most obvious examples of this are Yellow Devil Mk. I and Wily Machine I, both of which will make you rage if this is your first time through a Megaman game. (They still give me fits, and I've been playing them for years.)

There are good and bad parts to these games, but in the end... yeah, I enjoyed it.

I'm still mixed about the price- fifteen sounds a little expensive, and the cheapskate on my shoulder keeps telling me that this ought to be ten (when he's not off viciously mauling the few slices of pizza I intended on having for dinner)... and I'm inclined to believe him.

TL;DR: It's a nice solid title, but nothing to really write home about. Wait for a sale for a decent deal and grab it for ten at the most. 7/10.

A classic remake for a classic game!
It's no secret that I love Mega Man almost as much as I love Sonic the hedgehog. Despite the fact that Capcom hasn't given Mega Man any love in the past few years, it's still my favourite series.
One day, I'd like to see Mega Man and his alternate Net Navi counterpart return to glory.

While the Mega Man Legacy Collection wasn't everything I was looking for, it's better than plugging your vastly outdated NES in to either your smart TV or an old fashioned CRT television and watching the chaos ensue as you attempt to get the game to even run...


What is Mega Man / Rockman: Legact Collection?
So what exactly is in the Legacy Collection? Well, it's a package that includes the six original NES games, as well as a few digital upgrades and extras.

I know it sounds like a very simple port, but the games truly benefit from their digital enhancements.
Every game has the option of three aspect ratios (original, wide, and full), as well as two additional visual filters meant to replicate old CRT TVs and monitors.

That's basically all you get in terms of mixing up the games from the way they were originally presented.
That is, unless you count the Remix mode" which I'll discuss later.

Emulation or re-design...?
The key mantra from Digital Eclipse is "if it ain't broke don't fix it
date:
which is going to be a rather polarizing choice for many gamers out there that never grew up with Mega Man.

Personally, having grown up with the NES, I'm completely okay with things like slowdown effects and choppy, warped visuals to emulate the look of an NES release.
Yep, that's right!  The developers have opted to retain the original look and feel of the games, for better or for worse.

It's also worth noting that you won't find any quality of life improvements, such as the ability to switch between subweapons with the triggers which was a feature from the PSOne Classic re-releases a few generations ago.
In case you're wondering, yes, the Elec-Man subweapon pause glitch found on the original NES cartridge still works.

Mega cool extras!
There are some nice extras that can be found in the game, like a music player that features every original sound track from all six games, and a hefty database mode, which showcases artwork and concept art for every enemy in the game. It's all old archive material that exists in some developers’ artbook somewhere, but it's still nice to be able to flip through it all in one centralized location.
One really cool feature of the archive is the ability to instantly fight any Robot Master at will from the menu screen, with every weapon from that game at your disposal.
It's a nice little throw back for players that enjoy the boss battles, mirroring the arcade CPS2 Mega Man games in their Boss battle only approach to gameplay.

From NES to PC Ok, so onto Mega Man 1-6 how do they hold up? Quite well, actually...
The original Mega Man is a bit rough at times with some haphazard level design, bad enemy placement and off screen enemies being able to shoot you. However, these complaints are just as valid to the original game as this version.
In fact, with a few exceptions, the game is a pixel perfect replica of the original game.
The Blue Bomber seal of quality is immediately apparent upon progressing to the second game and of course, the third, which is my personal favourite of the original games.
While I did feel the burn with Mega Man 4 and 5 due to a lack of innovation, I enjoyed them all the same, and Mega Man 6 wowed me, just as it did when I was younger, with just how clean and interesting the game generally is.

My view on the stalwart commitment to the originals" is mixed

reviewText: It's easy to forget just how good 8-bit Mega Man is if you dont play for awhile. It's been along time since I had the drive to play through these classic games and oh man does this collection make me never want to stop. As far as recreations of these games go, this is the most faithful reproduction of the original game experience I have seen. The slowdown is there, every little flickering sprite glitch is remade in crisp 8-bit. If you dont like the crispness they have a couple filters to simulate the blur of a CRT which gave me some instant feelings of nostalgia. Outside of the games there is a good amount of production and concept art to look through for each game, there is a music player where you can listen to every song in the game, and then there is a challenge mode. The challenge mode reminds me a bit of NES Remix in that it mixes and reorganizes the games in different, more bite size ways to play. There are around 50 challenges I belive. Every challenge keeps track of your time and there are online leaderboards where you can see how you line up against other mega man players. If you just want to practice and get good at mega man as a genre, this is a cool way to learn and push yourself. I would say, I reccomend the PC version over the console versions, purley because of the display lag inherint in most modern TV's. I have also been playing on my PS4 and it is absurd how much better the games feel when I play them on the PC. The tightness of the controls really starts to shine, something I havnt felt since I played these games all thoose years ago. Overall it is well worth the 15$ to play through these games again and bring foward this formative time in video game design to a modern audience.

reviewText:
So, I am a life long Mega Man fan.  I have a Mega Man tattoo (he's jumping and shooting in all of his blue bomber 8 bit glory), I have keychains, I have all of the original cartridges and boxes-- I'm very into Mega Man.  Ever since I was a kid I was super into these games.  I always associated my love for the series with me imagining that I was Mega Man as a kid while playing.  He's this little white kid and I could relate to being a little white kid when I was 4 - 7 (I started my journey to being fat at 8).  But now that I gave you a little back story as to how much I love Mega Man, let's get into why I love the Legacy Collection and the one main issue I have with it.

First of all, you're getting 6 of some of the most creative and frustrating games, albeit tons of fun, that have ever been made in all of it's HD 8 bit sexiness.  That alone should be worth the 15 bucks you're forking over for a copy.  But what really blew me away about this collection is that you can put a graphics filter on while you're playing that makes it look like you're playing on a tube television.  and it is AUTHENTIC.  I was geeking out so hard on all the nostalgia that was happening when I found this function.  It was like I rediscovered how you should experience Mega Man.  Sure, it takes away from the HD perk of the games.  But who cares?  Some, probably.  But not me.  I'd much rather have the option to play my Mega Man games in crisp HD or with all the blemishes and ghost lines of an old tube tv.  So that really made me legitimately blissfully happy.
Another reason as to why you should buy this collection are the remix challenges.  I'm not going to lie, when I first started the challenges I was a little lackluster about them.  I was hoping you could play like your own version of Mega Man games by, say, playing Ice Man's stage and then after beating him you'd go to like... Heat Man's stage or something along those lines.  Like mixing up the robot bosses.  That isn't what you get at first.  BUT.  The more and more you unlock the challenges, the closer to that reality you get and the challenges become much more fun the more you complete them.
There are so many added goodies and functions that I probably would have paid 25 dollars for this collection of 25+ year old games.  But I do have a complaint.  It's not HUGE... but it certainly is frustrating.

...

I hate saying anything bad about anything Mega Man.  But this collection sometimes isn't the most responsive with the controls.  And it's not like oh

it's just cause it's a NES game."  No.  It's really not.  I've played all 6 of these games and beaten them countless times and the lagging issue in this game is not found in the original cartridges.  What I mean by lagging is sometimes if you want to move forward... it just won't move.  Does this happen often?  Lord no.  But does it happen?  Yes.  Will it make you want to throw your controller at the wall?  Most definitely.

BUT IN SAYING THAT...

I would not dismiss picking this package up solely based on that.  Enjoy revisiting these games and reclaiming a bit of that spark you felt when playing these as a little kid who looked up to Mega Man.  I sure did."

reviewText:
A classic remake for a classic game!
It's no secret that I love Mega Man almost as much as I love Sonic the hedgehog. Despite the fact that Capcom hasn't given Mega Man any love in the past few years, it's still my favourite series.
One day, I'd like to see Mega Man and his alternate Net Navi counterpart return to glory.

While the Mega Man Legacy Collection wasn't everything I was looking for, it's better than plugging your vastly outdated NES in to either your smart TV or an old fashioned CRT television and watching the chaos ensue as you attempt to get the game to even run...


What is Mega Man / Rockman: Legact Collection?
So what exactly is in the Legacy Collection? Well, it's a package that includes the six original NES games, as well as a few digital upgrades and extras.

I know it sounds like a very simple port, but the games truly benefit from their digital enhancements.
Every game has the option of three aspect ratios (original, wide, and full), as well as two additional visual filters meant to replicate old CRT TVs and monitors.

That's basically all you get in terms of mixing up the games from the way they were originally presented.
That is, unless you count the Remix mode" which I'll discuss later.

Emulation or re-design...?
The key mantra from Digital Eclipse is "if it ain't broke don't fix it
date:
which is going to be a rather polarizing choice for many gamers out there that never grew up with Mega Man.

Personally, having grown up with the NES, I'm completely okay with things like slowdown effects and choppy, warped visuals to emulate the look of an NES release.
Yep, that's right!  The developers have opted to retain the original look and feel of the games, for better or for worse.

It's also worth noting that you won't find any quality of life improvements, such as the ability to switch between subweapons with the triggers which was a feature from the PSOne Classic re-releases a few generations ago.
In case you're wondering, yes, the Elec-Man subweapon pause glitch found on the original NES cartridge still works.

Mega cool extras!
There are some nice extras that can be found in the game, like a music player that features every original sound track from all six games, and a hefty database mode, which showcases artwork and concept art for every enemy in the game. It's all old archive material that exists in some developers’ artbook somewhere, but it's still nice to be able to flip through it all in one centralized location.
One really cool feature of the archive is the ability to instantly fight any Robot Master at will from the menu screen, with every weapon from that game at your disposal.
It's a nice little throw back for players that enjoy the boss battles, mirroring the arcade CPS2 Mega Man games in their Boss battle only approach to gameplay.

From NES to PC Ok, so onto Mega Man 1-6 how do they hold up? Quite well, actually...
The original Mega Man is a bit rough at times with some haphazard level design, bad enemy placement and off screen enemies being able to shoot you. However, these complaints are just as valid to the original game as this version.
In fact, with a few exceptions, the game is a pixel perfect replica of the original game.
The Blue Bomber seal of quality is immediately apparent upon progressing to the second game and of course, the third, which is my personal favourite of the original games.
While I did feel the burn with Mega Man 4 and 5 due to a lack of innovation, I enjoyed them all the same, and Mega Man 6 wowed me, just as it did when I was younger, with just how clean and interesting the game generally is.

reviewText:
I have extremely mixed opinions on Mega Man Legacy Collection, but I am giving it a “Recommended” review because I support the Mega Man franchise. I very much hope that Capcom will at some point revive the series and announce another game, perhaps Mega Man 11 or maybe another remake like Mega Man Powered Up. But that’s beside the point.

Simply put, this is a collection of the six Mega Man games originally released from 1987 to 1994 on the Nintendo Entertainment System. There have been no changes whatsoever to the games except for the removal of “Licensed by Nintendo of America” on the title screens of MM1 and MM2. The games run in an emulator environment, so there’s save states for those who need them or don’t want to use the password system. Controller support is done well and I don’t notice any problems when using a Logitech F310 gamepad.

There is a plethora of official artwork and music to explore in the “Database” section of each game, and it is well worth your time to take a look, but most of the included material can be found for free on the Internet at sites like Mega Man Knowledge Base and YouTube.

The only major new addition is a “Challenge Mode”, clearly inspired by the challenges found in Mega Man 10. The challenges (of which there are about 50) consist entirely of rooms and bosses taken straight from the original games – there aren’t any new challenges with unique rooms as there were in MM10. This is a bit of a disappointment, but it’s perfectly understandable as the developers were trying to go for perfect emulation and as a result chose not to develop any new material. They’re also a nice way to practice fighting certain sets of Robot Masters.

The one really disappointing thing here is that Mega Man 7, Mega Man and Bass, and Mega Man: The Wily Wars are all absent from this compilation. I can understand not including Mega Man 8-10, because those were developed for more advanced platforms (PlayStation and Wii respectively), but the Super NES and Sega Genesis aren’t that hard to emulate on PCs. There’s no excuse for not including titles released on those systems. Besides, the original versions of Mega Man and Bass and Mega Man: The Wily Wars have never had an official release here in North America. It would have been a major selling point had those games been included.

It is really up to you whether or not to purchase this collection. I have included the following checklist to help you out with that decision. Please take a look.

If you…
•	do not already own any of the NES Mega Man games on another platform such as Virtual Console for Wii U, 3DS, etc.
•	are interested in supporting the Mega Man franchise and telling Capcom that we want them to stop ignoring it and do something new
•	want to play Mega Man 1-6 on PC without using emulators and “illegal” ROMs
•	want easy Steam achievements for beating the games
•	want to play the Challenge Mode with assorted challenges and quests from the games similar to that found in Mega Man 10
•	want to look at cool official artwork
•	don’t mind that every Mega Man game after MM6 is not included here

…then by all means, BUY THIS GAME! You will be 100% satisfied with what it has to offer.

However, if you…
•	already own any of the NES Mega Man games on another platform (or if you’re one of those people who actually has an NES with the cartridges)
•	have played through these games many times and can complete all of them in one sitting with few deaths
•	want Mega Man 7-10 and/or Wily Wars on PC
•	don’t care about the Steam achievements
•	are fine with looking at artwork on the Internet
•	are fine with using emulators

…then don’t buy. You will not find anything new or interesting.

I hope this review has helped you make a choice as to whether or not this game is worth your money. Thank you for taking the time to read and please rate up if it was helpful. =)

reviewText:
Let's face it- blowing up robots is awesome. Blowing them up and taking their special powers for personal use? Even better. Such is the premise of the Megaman series- a system that has influenced game design since its launch in 1987 (and which I remember playing on a console a year later, when I was six. I feel rather old at that realization).

The premise is rather simple- take the first bunch of stages in any order, amassing a pile of special weapons to take down the evil Dr. Wily and save the world from his latest evil scheme (yeah, it's safe to assume he doesn't really have a hobby) by blasting through Skull Castle . While the full Megaman series consists of several different games spread over how many consoles and time periods, this collection contains only a small slice of all that- for fifteen bucks retail, you get a pretty decent selection: the first six games of the main Megaman series, which were all released on the eight-bit Nintendo Entertainment System over a period of time from 1987 to 1994. You also get some behind-the-scenes stuff, like enemy backgrounds art assets and sketches, as well as the soundtracks to the six games (trust me, you'll run into plenty of earworm-type songs in these games) but I honestly don't understand why you'd include a music player when you could just fire up YouTube and listen to them there without having to go and boot Steam.

You also get a challenge mode- which shows lots of influence from a series of fangames that just throw you into sections from random levels and see how far you can get. This is actually rather fun- your powers are determined by which game you land in, and you get four E-Tanks to sustain you through the sequence, and you're scored on time taken. This forces you to think on your toes and use your memory to try and think of all your options at the current time.

There's a save system- you get one save point for each game that you can use to save at any point- just go into the menu, save, and it will allow you to load the game and pick up at that exact point. It's useful for when you're at the end of a level on your last life, and don't desire to play the level again.

This is also one of the only legitimate ways to get copies of these games outside of A) owning the original cartridges, B) buying the Megaman Anniversary Collection, or C) buying them off of Nintendo's Shop Channels (1 to 5 are on the Wii Shop channel, 6 is on the Wii U and 3DS shop channel). But that, well... leads into a bit of the downside to this collection.

Why is this only the first six games? There are ten in the main series alone, and you've got the main series, the X series, the Legends series... why not just tweak the Anniversary Collection and release that and ask twenty or twenty-five for it? Follow it up with the X Collection and the Legends games and you have a great way to reach another generation of gamers through Steam. Also, why no Wily Wars?

All of the games enclosed within are faithfully emulated, down to the screen flicker and original bugs and easter eggs (the Elec Beam/pause trick still works in the first game, and you can still get the Rush Jet in 3 without having to earn it if you know the trick). However, that means the sprite flicker and slowdown is in there, too.

The early games- especially the first game- are genuine Nintendo hard. The most obvious examples of this are Yellow Devil Mk. I and Wily Machine I, both of which will make you rage if this is your first time through a Megaman game. (They still give me fits, and I've been playing them for years.)

There are good and bad parts to these games, but in the end... yeah, I enjoyed it.

I'm still mixed about the price- fifteen sounds a little expensive, and the cheapskate on my shoulder keeps telling me that this ought to be ten (when he's not off viciously mauling the few slices of pizza I intended on having for dinner)... and I'm inclined to believe him.

TL;DR: It's a nice solid title, but nothing to really write home about. Wait for a sale for a decent deal and grab it for ten at the most. 7/10.
